Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Behavioral and Genetic Mechanisms for Frequency-Dependent Survival and Mating Advantage in Guppies
Award.AbstractNarration:
Behavioral and Genetic Mechanisms for Frequency-Dependent Survival and Mating Advantage in Guppies

IOB-0743990

Anne Houde

In the genomic era, it has become increasingly obvious that most traits that are relevant to the health, longevity, and fertility of organisms (including humans) are influenced by genetic variation (polymorphism). Despite intense interest in mapping and characterizing the responsible genes, the processes responsible for maintaining genetic variation are generally unknown. One reason is that direct experimental investigations are impossible in humans and difficult and expensive in most model organisms. More tractable species that can be studied in both natural and laboratory settings are needed to address this question. Wild guppies exhibit one of the most striking examples of polymorphism among animals (male color pattern variation), thought to be maintained by mating and survival advantages to rare or uncommon color types. Mating advantage appears result from female sexual responses to unusual males, and survival advantage appears to result from selective predation on common color types. This project will elucidate behavioral and genetic mechanisms underlying these patterns. Studies will examine (1) behavioral mechanisms leading to mating advantage for rare types, (2) behavioral responses of a predatory killifish to rare vs. common types and (3) brain gene expression changes that occur when guppies respond to novel sexual and environmental stimuli. Specific outcomes include determining (1) if female guppies have a specific preference for rare male types, (2) if prior experience with color types affects the predator's behavior and (3) which genes change their levels of expression in response to novel stimuli. This work will provide a clear picture of how behavioral and genetic processes contribute to genetic variation, and will also provide a model system for understanding response to novelty as a general phenomenon. Broader impacts of the project will include training of undergraduate and graduate students and further development of the guppy model system as a well-known exemplar for broad understanding of evolution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Why are individuals within species so genetically diverse?  This is the broad question on which the project focused.  Mutation is the raw material for diversity but mutations are sifted by natural selection. We might therefore expect individuals of the same species that inhabit the same environment to have very similar genomes. In fact, individuals vary enormously at the genetic level, even within local populations, and we do not understand why. We studied the processes that influence genetic diversity in a particular species in which the diversity is apparent and is amenable to experiments in the laboratory and in nature--the Trinidadian guppy.  Male guppies are highly colorful, but individual males from the same locale differ considerably in color, and these differences are passed from father to son.

In previous research we discovered two processes that could explain the high genetic diversity of male color patterns: males with rare color patterns are preferred as mates by females, and they also have lower mortality rates in natural populations. Both these patterns suggest that individual behavior is an important factor in promoting genetic diversity in guppies. That is, female guppy mating behavior and the behavior of guppy predators could promote diversity by increasing the fitness of any color variants that are rare. This kind of natural selection (where rare types are favored over comon ones) can maintain a great deal of genetic variation. In this project, we tested these two hypotheses:  that both guppy females and guppy predators behave in ways that maintain genetic diversity in guppies. 

Using laboratory studies, we found evidence supporting both hypotheses. First guppy predators (the killifish Rivulus hartii) become better at capturing male guppies the more familiar they are with the male's color pattern. When the killifish are presented with a male bearing an unfamiliar color pattern, their predation success declines. Second, guppy females prefer males who have color patterns different from the previous male to court, and they also prefer males with color patterns that are unique within a group (compared to males with color patterns that are similar to other males). We also found evidence that this strong female preference for rare male color patterns occurs in nature.  When we moved individual males among different pools within streams in Trinidad so that some males had rare and some had "common" patterns in their local pool, males with patterns that were made rare had more offspring and mated with more females than males with patterns that were made common.  

Given the strength and consistency of female guppy preference for rare or unfamiliar male color patterns, we asked whether this preference led them to avoid mating with related males in nature.  This kind of "inbreeding avoidance" is one reason why females might display a preference for males that look unfamiliar to them. Indeed, we found that females from a natural population produced were more likely to produce offspring with the males in their locale that were the most distantly related to them. 

We also found evidence that the brains of female guppies who are exposed to a novel male color pattern respond differently than the brains of females that are exposed to a familiar male color pattern. Surprisingly, this "brain genomic response" to unfamiliar-appearing males seems similar to the responses seen in other animals, including humans, that seek out novel environments or experiences. This result suggests that female preference for novel-appearing mates could have arisen as a byproduct of a more general kind of novelty seeking.
